description.narrative:
Bristen på tillgång till information är en av de huvudsakliga utmaningarna för etablerandet av god samhällsstyrning i Kambodja. Avsaknaden av en lag på informationsfrihetsområdet gör det svårt för medborgarna att ta del av offentlig information, trots att det är en tydligt uttryckt rättighet i den kambodjanska konstitutionen. Som ett resultat av detta försvåras befolkningens möjligheter att effektivt delta i demokratiska beslutsprocesser på olika nivåer och genom den bristande transparens bidrar det dessutom till att bekämpandet av korruption försvåras.
Den föreslagna insatsen ligger rätt i tiden och har möjlighet att fungera som katalysator för en inkluderande, deltagande och transparent lagstiftningsprocess på informationsfrihetsområdet. UNESCO har föreslagit föreliggande insats med syfte att komma till rätta med tillkortakommanden i tidigare lagstiftningsförsök genom att tydliggöra regerings ansvar i lagstiftningsprocessen samtidigt som civila samhällets representanter ges möjlighet att göra sin röst hörd.
Insatsen föreslår tre förenade ansatser för att komma till rätta med de problem som noterats under tidigare försök att arbeta fram en informationsfrihetslagstiftning; (1) upprättandet av en interministriell kommité som ansvarar för hela lagstiftningsprocessen; (2) en inkluderande, deltagande och transparent konsultationtsprocess som inkluderar samtliga relevanta aktörer; (3) bidra till att öka kännedomen om arbetet med en informationsfrihetslagstiftning för att stärka förståelsen av behovet hos gemene man.
Det svenska bidraget förväntas uppgå till 9 MSEK för en period av 36 månader.

The lacking access to information remains one of the main challenges in promoting good governance in Cambodia. The absence of adequate legislation makes it difficult for citizens to access public information, although their rights are recognized in the Cambodian Constitution. As a result, the people cannot effectively participate in decisionmaking.
The proposed intervention aims to promote a participatory, transparent and meaningful law making process. UNESCO has proposed the intervention in order to remedy the shortcomings of previous attempts of producing an access to information law, by reinforcing the government's role as initiator and respecting the demands of civil society. The intervention proposes three joined approaches: (1) establishing an interministerial committee that takes the lead in the law making process; (2) draft law consultations process carried out in a participatory, transparent and meaningful manner with all relevant stakeholders; and (3) raise awareness through media and campaigns for strengthening the demand for the law. Implementing this comprehensive scheme requires UNESCO to work and coordinate effectively with one government ministry (MoI) and three local NGOs.
The Swedish contribution would be 9 MSEK for the period of 36 months.

Cambodia has since its independence struggled to build and maintain democraticstructures, an independent judiciary system and an environment for free media. Goodgovernance and government accountability have lacked a legal framework to eversuccessfully take root. Consequently, opportunities for the public to influence on thedecision-making process have been lacking. After the National Assembly's rejection oftwo subsequent drafts on an Access to Information Law (A2I), submitted by CNRP, thenthe opposition party, the Royal Government of Cambodia indicated a strong politicalwill to draft a new law on A2I. The development intervention's overall objective is to promote an inclusive andparticipatory law-making process by bringing the government and citizens together indrafting an Access to Information Law in Cambodia. For the 2019 no-cost extension, please note that the objectives of the intervention havenot changed from the 2014 appraisal, but focus will be on objectives 2 and 3 rather thanobjective 1. The specific objectives of the intervention are as follows:1. To establish a functioning Technical Working Group and an inter-ministerialCommittee to draft and pass an Access to Information law.2. To promote participatory law making and to provide a bridge between thegovernment and the public for discussion on the drafting of the Access to InformationLaw.3. To increase demand for the Access to Information Law through the training of mediaprofessionals and implementation of an advocacy campaign.

tag.narrative: 16.10 - 0 Säkerställa allmän tillgång till information och skydda grundläggande friheter, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning och internationella avtal.
16.10 - Ensure public access to information and protect fundamental freedoms, in accordance with national legislation and international agreements.
16.5 - Substantially reduce corruption and bribery in all their forms.
16.5 - Väsentligt minska alla former av korruption och mutor.
16.6 - Bygga upp effektiva och transparenta institutioner med ansvarsutkrävande på alla nivåer.
16.6 - Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.

17.16 - Enhance the Global Partnership for Sustainable Development, complemented by multi-stakeholder partnerships that mobilize and share knowledge, expertise, technology and financial resources, to support the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals in all countries, in particular developing countries

17.16 - Enhance the Global Partnership for Sustainable Development, complemented by multi-stakeholder partnerships that mobilize and share knowledge, expertise, technology and financial resources, to support the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals in all countries, in particular developing countries.
5.b - Enhance the use of enabling technology, in particular information and communications technology, to promote the empowerment of women.
5.b - Öka användningen av gynnsam teknik, i synnerhet informations- och kommunikationsteknik, för att främja kvinnors egenmakt
9.c - Significantly increase access to information and communications technology and strive to provide universal and affordable access to the Internet in least developed countries by 2020.
9.c - Väsentligt ökad tillgången till informations- och kommunikationsteknik samt eftersträva allmän och ekonomiskt överkomlig tillgång till Internet i de minst utvecklade länderna senast 2020.

description.narrative: 1. To establish a functioning Technical Working Group and an inter-ministerial Committee to draft and pass an Access to Information law. Participation and Accountability- An A2I law has been drafted and is in the final stages of submission to the Council of ministers. Improvement of the draft law on A2I, where Government, as a duty bearer, took ownership in a participatory process, has since 2014 been worked on by a Technical Work Group, composed of government officials, CSO representatives, OHCHR, and UNESCO. Rights holders and duty bearers have collaborated in a participatory, and transparent process. The collaboration has promoted participation for duty bearers and accountability, in terms of involvement of government representatives creating a direct link to involved institutions. Empowerment-Over 70 government officials from MoI and line ministries have been equipped with capacities and knowledge on best practices and international standards of Access to Information, and participatory law-making processes. Duty bearers have been strengthened in their capacity to achieve their obligations. 2. To promote participatory law making and to provide a bridge between the government and the public for discussion on the drafting of the Access to Information Law. Empowerment -A participatory, inclusive, and transparent law-making process enabled, setting up a new model for legislative process in Cambodia. The empowerment of duty bearers by equipping them with a new approach to law-making has been especially prominent. Participation, Empowerment and Transparency- The Partner reports that input and feedback from CSOs, NGOs, media and the general public were incorporated in the draft law, through transparent and participatory platforms, allowing the public sphere to influence the decision-making process, bridging the gap between the government and the public. Over 60% of comments, input, and feedback from the mentioned sources, have been incorporated into the new draft law. - Over 40,000 people reached out through established participatory multimedia platforms. - 72 multimedia Information, Education and Communication products produced and broadcasted via radio and Facebook. A broad variety of actors has provided input for the draft law. Rights holders, as well as voicing organizations of different modalities, have been inquired for input. Content produced has been used to empower rights holders, informing them of rights such as Freedom of Expression and Access to Information. 3. To increase demand for the Access to Information Law through the training of media professionals and implementation of an advocacy campaign. Empowerment and Transparency- The consolidation of the efforts to promote Freedom of Expression, and Access to Information, by creating a Media Development Working group, including international and local organizations, the media, donors, and the UN. Consolidating efforts has put an end to fragmented actions. - The re-engagement of Government in discussions on Freedom of Expression, Access to Information and Media Development; as well as high-level participation in key events commemorating World Press Freedom Day, International Day of Universal Access to Information and World Radio Day. - The Partner reports that government representatives, as duty bearers, have enhanced their knowledge on international human rights standards in participatory policy and law making. A very valuable contribution to increasing the demand for the law. The consolidation of efforts represents a strengthening of possibilities for right holders to claim their rights, in this case by creating a platform for collaboration allowing information on Freedom of Expression and Access to Information to reach right holders in a concise manner. The empowerment of both technical and high-level government staff, in terms of knowledge of Freedom of Expression, Access to Information and Media Development has been an integral part of this objective.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
